member.name: T:MathNet.Filtering.Butterworth.Designer
member.summary: Computes the minimum order and the cutoff frequencies, starting from the design parameters of a Butterworth filter.

member.name: M:MathNet.Filtering.Butterworth.Designer.LowPass(System.Double,System.Double,System.Double,System.Double)
member.summary: Designs a low-pass Butterworth filter according to the specification.
member.param: Passband corner frequency, normalized to Nyquist frequency.
Stopband corner frequency, normalized to Nyquist frequency.
member.returns: Minimum required filter order and computed cutoff frequency.
member.exception: Passband corner frequency is not in [0,1] range.
Stopband corner frequency is not in [0,1] range.
Passband ripple must be a finite number.
Stopband attenuation must be a finite number.
Stopband corner frequency must be greater than passband corner frequency.
Stopband attenuation must be greater than passband ripple.

member.name: M:MathNet.Filtering.Butterworth.Designer.HighPass(System.Double,System.Double,System.Double,System.Double)
member.summary: Designs a high-pass Butterworth filter according to the specification.
member.param: Stopband corner frequency, normalized to Nyquist frequency.
Passband corner frequency, normalized to Nyquist frequency.
member.returns: Minimum required filter order and computed cutoff frequency.
member.exception: Passband corner frequency is not in [0,1] range.
Stopband corner frequency is not in [0,1] range.
Passband ripple must be a finite number.
Stopband attenuation must be a finite number.
Stopband corner frequency must be lesser than passband corner frequency.
Stopband attenuation must be greater than passband ripple.

member.name: M:MathNet.Filtering.Butterworth.Designer.BandPass(System.Double,System.Double,System.Double,System.Double,System.Double,System.Double)
member.summary: Designs a band-pass Butterworth filter according to the specification.
member.param: Lower stopband corner frequency, normalized to Nyquist frequency.
Lower passband corner frequency, normalized to Nyquist frequency.
Higher passband corner frequency, normalized to Nyquist frequency.
Higher stopband corner frequency, normalized to Nyquist frequency.
member.returns: Minimum required filter order and computed cutoff frequency.
member.exception: Lower passband corner frequency is not in [0,1] range.
Lower stopband corner frequency is not in [0,1] range.
Higher passband corner frequency is not in [0,1] range.
Higher stopband corner frequency is not in [0,1] range.
Passband ripple must be a finite number.
Stopband attenuation must be a finite number.
Lower stopband corner frequency must be lesser than lower passband corner frequency.
Lower passband corner frequency must be lesser than higher passband corner frequency.
Higher stopband corner frequency must be greater than higher passband corner frequency.
Stopband attenuation must be greater than passband ripple.

member.summary: HighPass, lets only high frequencies pass.

member.summary: BandPass, lets only frequencies pass that are inside of a band.

member.summary: BandStop, lets only frequencies pass that are outside of a band.

member.name: T:MathNet.Filtering.FIR.FirCoefficients
member.summary:
FirCoefficients provides basic coefficient evaluation algorithms for the four most important filter types for Finite Impulse Response (FIR) Filters.
Default filter order estimation: transition bandwidth is 25% of the lower passband edge, but not lower than 2 Hz, where possible (for bandpass, highpass, and bandstop) and distance from passband edge to critical frequency (DC, Nyquist) otherwise.

member.name: M:MathNet.Filtering.FIR.FirCoefficients.LowPass(System.Double,System.Double,System.Double,System.Int32)
member.summary: Calculates FIR LowPass Filter Coefficients.
member.param: Desired cutoff frequency in samples per unit.
half-order Q, so that Order N = 2*Q+1. 0 for default order.

member.name: M:MathNet.Filtering.FIR.FirCoefficients.HighPass(System.Double,System.Double,System.Int32)
member.summary: Calculates FIR HighPass Filter Coefficients.
member.param: Cutoff frequency in samples per unit.
half-order Q, so that Order N = 2*Q+1. 0 for default order.

member.name: M:MathNet.Filtering.FIR.FirCoefficients.BandPass(System.Double,System.Double,System.Double,System.Int32)
member.summary: Calculates FIR Bandpass Filter Coefficients.
member.param: Low Cutoff frequency in samples per unit.
High Cutoff frequency in samples per unit.
half-order Q, so that Order N = 2*Q+1. 0 for default order.

member.name: M:MathNet.Filtering.FIR.FirCoefficients.BandStop(System.Double,System.Double,System.Double,System.Int32)
member.summary: Calculates FIR Bandstop Filter Coefficients.
member.param: Low Cutoff frequency in samples per unit.
High Cutoff frequency in samples per unit.
half-order Q, so that Order N = 2*Q+1. 0 for default order.

member.name: T:MathNet.Filtering.FIR.OnlineFirFilter
member.summary: Finite Impulse Response (FIR) Filters are based on Fourier series and implemented using a discrete convolution equation. FIR Filters are always online, stable and causal.
member.remarks: System Description: H(z) = a0 + a1*z^-1 + a2*z^-2 + ...

member.name: M:MathNet.Filtering.FIR.OnlineFirFilter.#ctor(System.Collections.Generic.IList{System.Double})
member.summary: Finite Impulse Response (FIR) Filter.

member.summary: Process a single sample.

member.name: M:MathNet.Filtering.FIR.OnlineFirFilter.Reset
member.summary: Reset internal state (not coefficients!).

member.name: T:MathNet.Filtering.Helpers.Validators
member.summary: Exposes some common validation rules. Even though those check can be implemented in-place, it was deemed useful to keep them in a separate file to let the utilizers focus only on their goal.

member.summary: Checks that a double is a finite number.
member.exception: If the parameter is NaN or Infinity.

member.name: M:MathNet.Filtering.Helpers.Validators.CheckFrequency(System.Double,System.String)
member.summary: Checks that a frequency is normalized to the Nyquist rate, meaning that must be in [0;1] range.
member.exception: If the parameter is not in [0;1] range.

member.name: M:MathNet.Filtering.Helpers.Validators.CheckNull(System.Object,System.String)
member.summary: Explicitly checks that an object is not null
member.exception: If the parameter is null.

member.name: T:MathNet.Filtering.IIR.OnlineIirFilter
member.summary: Infinite Impulse Response (IIR) Filters need much less coefficients (and are thus much faster) than comparable FIR Filters, but are potentially unstable. IIR Filters are always online and causal. This IIR Filter implements the canonic Direct Form II structure.
member.remarks: System Description: H(z) = (b0 + b1*z^-1 + b2*z^-2) / (1 + a1*z^-1 + a2*z^-2)

member.name: M:MathNet.Filtering.IIR.OnlineIirFilter.#ctor(System.Double[])
member.summary: Infinite Impulse Response (IIR) Filter.

member.name: M:MathNet.Filtering.IIR.OnlineIirFilter.ProcessSample(System.Double)
member.summary: Process a single sample.

member.name: M:MathNet.Filtering.IIR.OnlineIirFilter.Reset
member.summary: Reset internal state (not coefficients!).

member.name: T:MathNet.Filtering.ImpulseResponse
member.summary: Specifies how a filter will respond to an impulse input.

member.name: F:MathNet.Filtering.ImpulseResponse.Finite
member.summary: Impulse response always has a finite length of time and are stable, but usually have a long delay.

member.name: F:MathNet.Filtering.ImpulseResponse.Infinite
member.summary: Impulse response may have an infinite length of time and may be unstable, but usually have only a short delay.

member.name: T:MathNet.Filtering.IOnlineFilter
member.summary: An online filter that allows processing samples just in time. Online Filters are always causal.

member.summary: Process a single sample.

member.summary: Process a whole set of samples at once.

member.name: M:MathNet.Filtering.IOnlineFilter.Reset
member.summary: Reset internal state (not coefficients!).

member.name: T:MathNet.Filtering.Median.OnlineMedianFilter
member.summary: Median-Filters are non-linear filters, returning the median of a sample window as output. Median-Filters perform well for de-noise applications where it's important to not loose sharp steps/edges.

member.summary: Create a Median Filter

member.summary: Process a single sample.

member.summary: Reset internal state.

member.name: T:MathNet.Filtering.OnlineFilter
member.summary: Online filters allow processing incoming samples immediately and hence provide a nearly real-time response with a fixed delay.

member.summary: Create a filter to remove high frequencies in online processing scenarios.

member.summary: Create a filter to remove high frequencies in online processing scenarios.

member.summary: Create a filter to remove low frequencies in online processing scenarios.

member.summary: Create a filter to remove low and high frequencies in online processing scenarios.

member.summary: Create a filter to remove low and high frequencies in online processing scenarios.

member.summary: Create a filter to remove middle (all but low and high) frequencies in online processing scenarios.

member.summary: Create a filter to remove middle (all but low and high) frequencies in online processing scenarios.

member.name: M:MathNet.Filtering.OnlineFilter.CreateDenoise(System.Int32)
member.summary: Create a filter to remove noise in online processing scenarios.
member.param: Window Size, should be odd. A larger number results in a smoother response but also in a longer delay.
member.remarks: The de-noise filter is implemented as an unweighted median filter.

member.name: M:MathNet.Filtering.OnlineFilter.CreateDenoise
member.summary: Create a filter to remove noise in online processing scenarios.
member.remarks: The de-noise filter is implemented as an unweighted median filter.

member.summary: Reset internal state (not coefficients!).

member.summary: Returns the cached ResourceManager instance used by this class.

member.summary: Overrides the current thread's CurrentUICulture property for all resource lookups using this strongly typed resource class.

member.summary: Looks up a localized string similar to Covariance matrix must be square..

member.summary: Looks up a localized string similar to Measurement covariance should be a square matrix with rows/cols equal to number of measurements..

member.summary: Looks up a localized string similar to Measurements should be a single column matrix..

member.summary: Looks up a localized string similar to Measurement sensitivity matrix should contain same number of rows as measurement matrix and columns as there are state variables..

member.summary: Looks up a localized string similar to Noise coupling matrix should have number of rows equal to number of state variables, and columns equal to process noise rows..

member.summary: Looks up a localized string similar to Square noise covariance matrices should have same number of rows/cols as state variables..

member.summary: Looks up a localized string similar to Kalman Filter state must be a column vector..

member.name: P:MathNet.Filtering.Properties.Resources.KFStateTransitionMalformed
member.summary: Looks up a localized string similar to State Transition should be square matrix with same rows/cols as state variables..

member.name: T:MathNet.Filtering.TransferFunctions.BilinearTransform
member.summary: Transform the list of zeros and poles (adjusting the gain accordingly) of a transfer function through the bilinear transform.

member.name: M:MathNet.Filtering.TransferFunctions.BilinearTransform.Apply(System.Double,System.Numerics.Complex[],System.Numerics.Complex[],System.Double)
member.summary: Applies the bilinear transform starting from the set of zeros and poles.
member.param: Sampling time, computed as the inverse of sampling frequency.
member.returns: Recomputed gain, list of zeros and list of poles.
member.exception: The gain must be a finite value.
The sampling time must be a finite value.
The list of zeros must be not null.
The list of poles must be not null.
The number of poles must at least be equal to the number of zeros.
member.remarks: For performance reasons, the method edits the input list of zeros and poles in-place when feasible, so the input and output arrays might be the same object.

member.name: T:MathNet.Filtering.TransferFunctions.TransferFunctionTransformer
member.summary: Transforms the zeros, the poles and the gain of a low-pass or band-pass prototype to the required filter type.

member.name: M:MathNet.Filtering.TransferFunctions.TransferFunctionTransformer.LowPass(System.Double,System.Numerics.Complex[],System.Numerics.Complex[],System.Double)
member.summary: Recomputes the gain and the list of zeros and poles for a low-pass filter.
member.returns: Recomputed gain, list of zeros and list of poles.
member.remarks: For performance reasons, the method edits the input list of zeros and poles in place, so the input and output arrays are actually the same object.

member.name: M:MathNet.Filtering.TransferFunctions.TransferFunctionTransformer.HighPass(System.Double,System.Numerics.Complex[],System.Numerics.Complex[],System.Double)
member.summary: Recomputes the gain and the list of zeros and poles for a high-pass filter.
member.returns: Recomputed gain, list of zeros and list of poles.
member.remarks: For performance reasons, the method edits the input list of zeros and poles in place, so the input and output arrays are actually the same object.

member.name: M:MathNet.Filtering.TransferFunctions.TransferFunctionTransformer.BandPass(System.Double,System.Numerics.Complex[],System.Numerics.Complex[],System.Double,System.Double)
member.summary: Recomputes the gain and the list of zeros and poles for a band-pass filter.
member.returns: Recomputed gain, list of zeros and list of poles.
member.remarks: For performance reasons, the method edits the input list of zeros and poles in place, so the input and output arrays are actually the same object.

member.name: M:MathNet.Filtering.TransferFunctions.TransferFunctionTransformer.BandStop(System.Double,System.Numerics.Complex[],System.Numerics.Complex[],System.Double,System.Double)
member.summary: Recomputes the gain and the list of zeros and poles for a band-stop filter.
member.returns: Recomputed gain, list of zeros and list of poles.
member.remarks: For performance reasons, the method edits the input list of zeros and poles in place, so the input and output arrays are actually the same object.

member.summary: Copy the window coefficients to a double array.

member.name: P:MathNet.Filtering.Windowing.Window.Width
member.summary: Window width, number of samples. Typically an integer power of 2, must be greater than 0.

member.name: P:MathNet.Filtering.Windowing.Window.Item(System.Int32)
member.summary: Window coefficients
member.param: window sample index, between 0 and Width-1 (inclusive).

member.name: T:MathNet.Filtering.Windows.PermanentWindow`1
member.summary: Window which is remains intact even if it propagates to the next window. Still much more efficient than creating a new buffer for every window, but somewhat less efficient than the volatile window. Newest value is the first one at Offset in BufferA, the next older one at Offset+1, wrapping around at BufferA.Length to BufferB.

member.name: T:MathNet.Filtering.Windows.VolatileWindow`1
member.summary: Window which is destroyed/modified as soon as it propagates to the next window. Efficient, but needs to be consumed immediately when streaming through windows. Newest value is the first one at Offset, the next older one at Offset+1, wrapping around at Buffer.Length.
